Same here but more motion graphics. Learnt while I was at Uni because it seemed fun and now I'm paid 25000 a year to do my hobby.

In my second year of university I realised I had signed up for a potentially useless arts degree. (turned out I was correct.) I had a lot of spare time though so I taught myself animation and graphic design. I now make motion graphics full time for TV. I'm literally paid to do what I did at home for free.
Tldr. University time hobby now myand super fun full time job.

WRITING.TEXT:
Having played tonnes of 1v1s I have played much more 2v2, 3v3 and 4v4 the past year or so.
They are all completely different.
1v1 - You are responsible for your own actions completely, if you fuck up then you have to fix it. On the flipside you are in complete control and can carry out a coordinated attack without worrying about your team-mate bailing on you or mis-timing things.
2v2 - Teamwork is everything. I only play with people on skype so we get things pretty tight. The key here is to pick two completely different doctrines to fill in each others weak spots and work as one. Its tempting to storm up each side of the map separately but i've noticed the better players roam around separately and then when making contact bring all the troops together on the conflicted point from different angles.
3v3 - Playing this most of all recently. Its a very free-form game and it generally ends up splitting like a 1v1 and a 2v2 all in the same game. The trick is to stay loose and not try to dig in as a single player. If three teams converge on a load of emplacements there is going to be a lot of wasted manpower.
4v4 - Again, played a fair bit of this as a skype team and it divulges into two 2v2 games a lot of the time. generally the maps are quite big so this woks pretty well as a basis. There is often tonnes of room for flanking though so use this to your advantage/dont get caught out!

I guess it's kind of touristy but 5 years later I love my tattoo. Went sailing to the marquess islands and got it done freehand by the cousin of the guy who owned the yacht supply shop. It was a teeny island too so all the locals popped their heads in as it was being done. Stayed there for a week after and got to know everyone on the island because of that, now every time I look at it I think of all those smiling faces!

'side by side' made by Keanu the Reeves, a documentary about cinema's paradigm shift from celluloid film to digital recording and work flow.
If you like films watch this. It has interviews with every top director from George lucas to Danny Boyle. It explains things in a really simple way but has enough technicalities and trivia to keep even die hard movie enthusiasts like me engaged from start to finish!

I usually describe it as a musky pungent earthy smell. Which is pretty vague I know!
Did you visit the Tuamotos at all south of marquesas? After the big green mountains those little thin desert islands were a big change of scenery!

It was such a crazy place. We got there after 33 days at sea with nothing to see but a few flying fish and a lot of waves. Then waking up to see these huge mountains stabbing out of the water was incredible. I remember the smell of land too as we were getting close!
The food was definitely amazing, would you ever go back?

Firstly take the roll out of the cardboard box.
For saran wrap just wrap whatever you're wrapping and cut the plastic with a sharp knife, hell even your fingernail against the counter top will score it enough. Failing that just stab it in a line roughly in a line where you want it to tear then pull and it will come off fairly evenly.
For foil just rip it, its pretty difficult to fuck that up.

WRITING.TITLE: Good resources for bondage.
WRITING.TEXT:
We have restraints and rope but after tying down (face forward, face up), hog tying, frog tying I'm starting to lose my creativity a bit.
Are there any good online resources to get some more ideas and to learn a bit better technique?
My knots aren't too bad but they definitely aren't the easiest to get out of in a pinch! so it would be brilliant to learn some more elegant techniques. Not to mention I'd love to get her to learn a bit better; she sucks at tying me up so anything from beginner to advanced is welcome!

You've been to a lot of the same islands as me! I sailed from the Galapagos to Tahiti (via Marquesas and Tuamotos).
No questions really apart from what did you think of french polinisia? (Marquesas islands especially). I spent a good while on Nuku Hiva and got a really cool tattoo from the cousin of the guy that owns the yacht supply shop!

Your best friend can become your worst enemy. Simply because of the way he chews.
I sailed from the galapagos to the marquesas islands for 35 days. That's roughly 33 days with no land even in sight. When you spend that long in confinement with the same people you start to notice minute details about them that drive you insane.

A that never had formal training in graphic design.
WRITING.TEXT:
I've checked out all the links in the sidebar but my book budget only does so far so i could do with a little advice!
I have been making motion graphics for TV for about a year now but before this i studied music and sound design. Everything I know, graphic design wise, is self taught and therefore i feel like my knowledge of the basics will always be incomplete!
Without the time or funds to take a year or two and do a course, which books or resources would you recommend above all that will give a good coverage of fundamental concepts?
EDIT: For anyone interested: [my showreel](http://mattcooksey.com/)

How are you finding that LED light and what wattage is it? My last grow didn't go so smoothly due to water issues but i was also growing under LEDs which i could never properly judge having used CFLs and HIDs before.

IIRC I played around with it when i was about 16. I remember it being remarkably easy to get into if you have even the slightest bit of coordination! Also there isnt too much to worry about with fire poi.
You are using Paraffin (Kerosine in the US) which has a pretty low burning temperature. Just don't wear anything you care about too dearly or use hair spray!

But do you really want to give up your actual personal memory of every beautiful moment?
Think of every time you have re-watched a film you loved as a child but is now cheesy, predictable and dull. Your memory stored and colored that experience based on everything that made you who you were at the time. You are a different person experiencing the film now.
Now imagine your first kiss, first time driving a car, last time you went to a fancy restaurant or a crazy party. Your imagination has colored some of these experiences and photos could never do them justice, Facebook has documented others extremely well so you can always go back and look at that evening exactly as it was forever more.
But with more and more information recorded, will we remember what it was like right there and then?

And see your wife doing something odd that catches your attention.
And keep thinking about it for the rest of your day.
And keep going back to it and other abstract memories to see try and find some kind of meaning.
And drag up old relationships your wife has had then argue and go to bed in silence.
And eventually find the last piece of the puzzle that fits into place and confirms your slumbering suspicions.
And then you kill your wife.
